question: Is there a good case for stating that there is a God?

content.source_1: Borde, A.; Guth, A. H.; Vilenkin, A. (2003). Inflationary spacetimes are not past-complete. Physical Review Letters, 90(15), 151301. Proves that any universe with a positive average expansion rate cannot be past-eternal, implying a beginning to spacetime—often cited in cosmological arguments that infer a transcendent cause.
content.source_2: Barnes, L. A. (2012). The Fine-Tuning of the Universe for Intelligent Life. Publications of the Astronomical Society of Australia, 29, 529–564. Surveys physics literature showing life-permitting values of constants occupy a very narrow range; framed as evidential support for design by theists, while also outlining naturalistic alternatives (e.g., multiverse, selection effects).
content.source_3: Swinburne, R. (2004). The Existence of God (2nd ed.). Oxford University Press. Presents a Bayesian “cumulative case” that a simple theistic hypothesis best explains a suite of data (existence of a contingent universe, laws of nature, consciousness, moral awareness, and religious experience), yielding a non-negligible posterior probability for God.
content.source_4: Rowe, W. L. (1979). The Problem of Evil and Some Varieties of Atheism. American Philosophical Quarterly, 16(4), 335–341. Argues from apparently gratuitous suffering (e.g., a fawn dying painfully in a forest fire) that the observed distribution of pain and pleasure is evidence against an all-good, all-powerful God.
content.source_5: Schellenberg, J. L. (1993). Divine Hiddenness and Human Reason. Cornell University Press. Develops the “hiddenness” argument: the existence of reasonable, nonresistant nonbelievers is surprising on the hypothesis of a perfectly loving God who desires relationship, thus evidencing against theism.
content.source_6: Barrett, J. L. (2012). Born Believers: The Science of Children’s Religious Belief. Free Press. Presents cognitive science findings that humans are predisposed to detect agency and purpose, offering a naturalistic explanation for widespread theistic belief and experiences without positing a real deity.
